summary: This is an internal email chain from February 2019 discussing the Department of Justice's opening of an investigation by its Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) into the 2008 plea deal negotiated for Jeffrey Epstein. The email references a Miami Herald article and a request from Senator Ben Sasse.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Wealthy New York investor accused of molesting more than 100 underage girls in Palm Beach, who received a lenient plea deal in 2008.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.role: Secretary of Labor, former U.S. Attorney
persons.context: As the former U.S. attorney for the Southern District of Florida, he negotiated the controversial 2008 plea deal with Jeffrey Epstein, which is now under investigation.

persons.name: Ben Sasse
persons.context: Nebraska Republican and member of the Senate Judiciary Committee who requested the DOJ investigation into the Epstein plea deal.

persons.name: Julie K. Brown
persons.context: Miami Herald reporter who authored the series 'Perversion of Justice' detailing the Epstein case and plea deal.

persons.name: Stephen E. Boyd
persons.context: DOJ official who wrote a letter to Senator Sasse confirming the OPR investigation into potential professional misconduct by Department attorneys in the Epstein matter.

connections.description: Acosta, as U.S. Attorney, negotiated the 2008 plea deal for Epstein, which is the subject of the OPR investigation.
Senator Sasse requested an investigation, and Boyd, as Assistant Attorney General, formally responded confirming the OPR probe.
Brown's investigative journalism for the Miami Herald exposed the details of the Epstein case and plea deal, prompting official scrutiny.

events.title: Epstein Plea Deal Negotiation
events.description: U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta and other DOJ attorneys worked with defense attorneys to negotiate a lenient plea deal for Jeffrey Epstein, accused of molesting over 100 underage girls.

events.title: DOJ Opens OPR Investigation
events.description: The Department of Justice's Office of Professional Responsibility opens an investigation into potential professional misconduct by DOJ attorneys in the resolution of the Epstein criminal matter.

keyFacts: The Department of Justice opened an investigation in February 2019 into the 2008 plea deal for Jeffrey Epstein, focusing on potential professional misconduct by DOJ attorneys.
The investigation was prompted by a request from Senator Ben Sasse following the Miami Herald's 'Perversion of Justice' series by Julie K. Brown.
The plea deal was negotiated by then-U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta and other DOJ attorneys with Epstein's defense team.
Jeffrey Epstein was accused of molesting more than 100 underage girls in Palm Beach.
The investigation is being conducted by the DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR).
